author: Nistula Hebbar
text:
A signal to BJP not to dig itself deeper into campus protests

A student staging a protest during Prime Minister Narendra Modi's speech at the convocation of Babasaheb Bhimrao Ambedkar University in Lucknow on Friday.— PHOTO: RAJEEV BHATT

At the end of a week when his party colleagues described Dalit research scholar Rohith Vemula, as “psychologically disturbed” after reading his suicide note, and even questioned his Dalit identity, Prime Minister Narendra Modi termed his death a “loss to Mother India”.

Mr. Modi’s comments in Lucknow on Friday, at the convocation ceremony of Ambedkar University, were specific enough to mention Rohith’s name, but ambiguous enough about laying blame.

Political opponents such as the Congress questioned Mr. Modi’s words. “BJP general secretary Muralidhar Rao questions Rohith’s Scheduled Caste status, Smt Irani justifies suspension of Ph.D. students, Modi ji says I am pained. What is true,” asked All India Congress Committee general secretary Randeep Surjewala.

Significantly, the Prime Minister’s words came at the same time as HRD Minister Smriti Irani spoke to Vemula’s mother and assured her of a judicial inquiry into the death of her son.

BJP general secretary Muralidhar Rao who, during a Twitter chat on Thursday, questioned Vemula’s identity as a Dalit, said: “The Central government’s decision for a judicial commission on the Hyderabad University issue should be welcomed, shows government’s sensitivity and accountability.”

Smriti Irani justifies suspension, Modi says I am pained; which is true,

asks Congress
title: PM breaks silence on suicide
